bibl.title: Interview with Merritte W. Ireland, by [Jessie Daniel Ames], October 22, 1929

div1.p: Ireland refuses to include Ames among the yellow fever heroes. He minimizes Ames' role in the yellow fever work, and advises [Jessie Daniel Ames] to give up in her attempt to have him honored.

div1.head: Interview with Merritte W. Ireland, by [Jessie Daniel Ames], October 22, 1929
div1.p: Interview with Surgeon General Ireland - October 22nd, 1929.

General Ireland is brusque and plain-spoken accord-
ing to his picture of himself. He left the impression that he was
following bulldozing tactics to beat down any initiative. He
started out by accusing me of reflecting discreditably upon the
memory of Doctor Ames in a letter written to his Department last
spring, and upbraiding me. He said Doctor Ames' record was be-
yond reproach and advised me to forget the whole affair. Since
General Ireland objects to having words put in his mouth, I shall
add that those were his exact words but his gestures and his tones
of voice made me feel that he meant me to go back home and forget
the whole question of recognition and he would charitably forget
that I had dishonored the memory of my husband. In reply to my
statement that his department was the guilty party he brusquely
informed me that he had no sympathy with me. In reply to the
statement that I was not asking for sympathy, he said he meant
with my attitude. He made me feel that he thought I was guilty
of lesemajesty if not treason in imputing guilt to the Department.
He also said the less said about my husband being non-immune and
having had Yellow Fever the better, and again he told me “to for-
get it”. He did admit that the official war record did show that
Doctor Ames had had Yellow Fever and while in the Experimental
Camp. He left me under the impression that he was trying to con-
vey to me that there was something discreditable; something which
should he hushed up; if it were pushed back too far something
highly unpleasant would be discovered from which he was trying to
shield me. He said that the record of the case was official, cer-
tified to by Major Alex Stark. I felt that as with Colonel Kean
that this fact embarrassed him. He said that Doctor Ames had
had a wonderful opportunity to serve, a privilege which he, General
Ireland, would have welcomed. He also said that literally thou-
sands of persons were seeking recognition. He inferred to my mind
that every one in Cuba during active hostilities and throughout
the occupation of Cuba might be considered as eligible as Doctor
Ames. He spoke three times of a guard who served at the Experi-
mental Camp seeking recognition. He seemed to imply that the
guard and Doctor Ames made a contribution of equal value. How-
ever, when asked if he did, he brusquely denied that was his
intention, but I could take it that way if I wished. He said
that the whole affair started thro an interest a Mr. Peabody took
in the case of the private Kissinger, who was paralyzed from his
waist down. He said that no doubt I knew how the women were added.
I did not ask him to enlarge, but I did not know. He said he
did not know what other surgeons, if any, were with Doctor Ames
in charge of the camps. Colonel Kean would know. He said Doctor
Ames had a wonderful record, one of which to be proud. That no
one who had received recognition had sought it. That it had
come unsought and tho he knew my husband slightly that he knew
that he would never be seeking recognition for his services but
that the consciousness of services rendered and a noble duty
done would be sufficient. When reminded that Doctor Ames had
been dead fourteen years, he said he knew it. Again he made me
feel as tho he was trying to convey to me that I was doing some-
thing unworthy of my husband. He said that he and Colonel Kean
had told me of the wonderful service my husband rendered and what
more should I want? When he was asked how this would be trans-
mitted to Doctor Ames' children, two of whom never knew their
father, and the other only vaguely, he replied by asking what I
wanted. When I told him that I wanted the same recognition for
my husband who was the trained expert in charge of the camps and
who was a non-immune and who had had Yellow Fever while the work
was on, he said he would never agree to add Doctor Ames' name
to that Act since it was limited to those who offered their
bodies and who did the scientific work (possibly meaning labora-
tory work) and that for me never to believe that had not Doctor
Ames offered his services, trained as they were, there would no
have been hundreds of others who would have. Again he left me
under the impression that he was making light of the work done
by Doctor Ames and that I should feel the same. He agreed to
collaborate with Colonel Kean and write an official testimony
of my husband's record in Cuba when I should make such a request
of the Adjutant General.

Our interview was one hour long. I judge General
Ireland to be of that type of military man who refuses to alter
his stand, feeling that no officer can make a wrong decision.
